text: Do you really have a use case where this parameter is useful?
Good idea!, ok, I will do this in the afternoon.
All aspects should have been addressed now.
Thanks for the advice, I tried to remedy accordingly.
You have to use `from nilearn._utils.testing import assert_raises_regexp` so that it works with Python 2.6
Shouldn't there be a 's', i.e. length**s**?

> I believe the verbose argument is generally an int rather than a boolean in
> nilearn.

Both work, as False is equivalent to 0 and True to 1.
Nosetest tells me that lines 290-297 are not tested. If it is the case, could you add a test ?
Besides the test aspect,  the PR looks good to me.
This could be a assert_array_equal, right?

> Sure, but I meant more as a general convention. It seems most of the code I
> have seen in nilearn does verbose=0 by default and does a greater than
> comparison for printing debug information.

The greater than will also work with ints. I have no preference.
